messageBody:
If you want to know _how_ to do it, a quick way with this code.
Should override "protected JFrame createUI(String suiteName)" to add
button+textfield to make changes possible...
This is not meant to be production quality, of course
_____________________________________
package junit.swingui;

import java.awt.event.*;
import javax.swing.*;

public class ContinuousTestRunner extends TestRunner {
public ContinuousTestRunner() {
}
protected JButton createRunButton(){
JButton button = super.createRunButton();
SwingUtilities.invokeLater(createAutomatedRunner(button));
return button;
}
public Runnable createAutomatedRunner(AbstractButton button){
//every 10 secs
return new ButtonClicker(1000*10, button);
}
class ButtonClicker implements Runnable, ActionListener {
AbstractButton button=null;
Timer timer;
ButtonClicker(int delay, AbstractButton button){
ButtonClicker.this.button=button;
timer = new Timer(delay, ButtonClicker.this);
timer.setRepeats(true);
timer.setInitialDelay(200);
}
public void run(){
timer.start();
}
public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e){
button.doClick();
}
}
public static void main(String[] args) {
new ContinuousTestRunner().start(args);
}


}_____________________________________
Hello,
Was wondering if there exists a JUnit extension that allows JUnit to run
tests every x minutes (every eg 30 minutes).
Preferable this would run in a JUnit GUI like junit.swingui.TestRunner, but
with the option to check-enable repeatative testing, and specify an interval
like every x minutes.
Repeatative testing is interesting to check a development that depends on
several dependancies (legacy applications) that tend to change over time (eg
go down, be modified, etc)
I experimented to implement/extend junit.swingui.TestRunner but without a
lot of success so far.
Any suggestions are welcomed.
Thanks,
Dirk Lecluse
